oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Chet Atkins Interview/Performance at Blair School of Music.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Chet Atkins being interviewed and performing at The Blair School Of Music.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Chet Atkins
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:10) -- Introduction of Chet Atkins by the dean of Blair School of Music. (2:45) -- Chet Atkins self-introduction to audience. Chet describes his family history. His father was a voice/piano teacher and piano tuner. His parents were divorced early on. (4:00) -- Chet Atkins speaks about his half-brother, who was a guitar player. (5:08) -- Chet Atkins speaks about learning ukulele at a young age before guitar. (5:50) -- Chet Atkins speaks on the difficulties of first learning the guitar at a young age. (6:24) -- Chet Atkins mentions that the first guitar player he heard was Karl Farr of The Sons of The Pioneers. (8:18) -- Chet Atkins describes his brother's first job in Nebraska playing on a radio station singing country music. (8:36) -- Chet Atkins describes his brother's work on the National Barn Dance. His brother met Rhubarb Red (Les Paul) there. (9:49) -- Chet Atkins mentions that Les Paul's guitar idol was Django Reinhardt. (10:23) -- Chet Atkins discusses working for the WLX Orchestra in Knoxville. "The boss of the show would let me play a solo, every other day or so" - Chet Atkins. (11:27) -- Chet Atkins discusses the difficulties of learning tunes and the guitar before method books were popularized. (11:48) -- Chet Atkins discusses the influence of Django Reinhardt's guitar playing. (12:29) -- Chet Atkins describes first hearing Merle Travis on his hand-built radio. (13:50) -- Chet Atkins mentions accidentally discovering his method of playing guitar like a stride piano player. Chet was trying to emulate Merle Travis, but ended up developing his own technique for solo guitar arrangements. (15:25) -- Chet Atkins speaks about his early success. "If you wonder why I've been successful, it's because I got there first." - Chet Atkins. (17:40) -- Chet Atkins introduces his daughter, Merle Atkins. (17:58) -- John Johns' introduction of Chet Atkins and Jim Fogelsong. (18:28) -- John Johns asks Chet Atkins about the first fiddle he owned. (19:10) -- Chet Atkins still owns his first fiddle. (19:42) -- Chet Atkins explains exactly when he first decided to become a guitar player. (21:06) -- Chet Atkins mentions a few guitar players from Kentucky that influenced him - Mose Rager, Ike Everly, and Kennedy Jones. Chet mentions that Mose Rager. (21:56) -- Chet Atkins tells a story about building a gymnasium at the age of 15 for NYA (National Youth Administration) in order to save enough money for an amplifier and guitar pickup. (23:05) -- Chet Atkins describes playing gigs without electricity. (23:55) -- John Johns asks Chet Atkins about his autobiography, "Country Gentleman", asks Chet to tell a story about his work on the radio. (26:08) -- Chet Atkins discusses making his first professional recording in 1945. (27:47) -- John Johns asks Chet Atkins about the layout of the first recording studios. (28:38) -- Chet Atkins discusses working with Steve Sholes. (29:02) -- Chet Atkins mentions Steve Sholes buying Elvis Presley's contract from Sun Records in 1955. Chet worked as Steve Sholes assistant at first. (30:48) -- Chet Atkins discusses how he was able to work in the music business and as a performer/arranger at the same time for over twenty years. (33:45) -- Chet Atkins speaks about how learning the melody to a song in fifteen different places on the guitar helped his arranging abilities. (34:30) -- "There's good music and melodies everywhere. It's in all the different areas of music." - Chet Atkins. (35:03) -- "The words in country music are more important than the melody, unfortunately. But once in a while somebody will write a song that has both - a great melody and great lyric." - Chet Atkins. (37:34) -- Chet Atkins speaks about Dolly Parton's songwriting. (40:15) -- Chet Atkins speaks about Jerry Reed's influence on his guitar playing. (41:18) -- Chet Atkins plays an instrumental written by Jerry Reed. (43:15) -- Chet Atkins plays a snippet of "Scarecrow." (44:58) -- John Johns asks Chet Atkins when he first became interested in playing a 'classical' guitar, or nylon string guitar. (46:10) -- Chet Atkins discusses playing guitar for Segovia.
